metadata.subject: chemistry
metadata.dotPoint: Extraction and purification of organic compounds from natural sources

solvent-extraction.name: Solvent Extraction
solvent-extraction.correct: Solvent extraction separates compounds based on their different solubilities in immiscible solvents

based on boiling point.fix: Extraction uses solubility differences; distillation uses boiling point differences

uses miscible solvents.fix: Solvents must be immiscible (form separate layers) for extraction to work
uses miscible solvents.action: Common pair: aqueous and organic (e.g., water and dichloromethane)

removes all compounds equally.fix: Different compounds partition differently between solvents based on polarity
removes all compounds equally.action: Like dissolves like: polar compounds prefer aqueous layer

persistent.gap: Not understanding extraction as polarity-based separation
persistent.action: Polar compounds go to water; non-polar compounds go to organic solvent

partition-coefficient.name: Partition Coefficient
partition-coefficient.correct: Partition coefficient describes how a compound distributes between two immiscible solvents

always equals 1.error: Missing the variable nature of K
always equals 1.fix: K varies for each compound depending on its polarity and the solvents used
always equals 1.action: K > 1 means compound prefers organic; K < 1 means prefers aqueous

indicates boiling point.fix: Partition coefficient relates to solubility distribution, not boiling point
indicates boiling point.action: K describes WHERE compound goes, not when it boils

only applies to pure compounds.fix: Each compound in a mixture has its own K value
only applies to pure compounds.action: Different K values allow separation of mixture components

persistent.gap: Not using K to predict extraction behaviour
persistent.action: Higher K = better extraction into organic layer

separating-funnel.name: Separating Funnel
separating-funnel.correct: A separating funnel allows physical separation of immiscible liquid layers

mixes the layers permanently.fix: Separating funnel allows layers to settle and be drained separately
mixes the layers permanently.action: Shake to equilibrate, settle to separate, drain to collect

the denser layer is always on top.fix: Denser layer sinks to bottom; drain bottom layer first via stopcock
the denser layer is always on top.action: Water (d=1.0) sinks below most organic solvents but floats on DCM

requires heating.error: Extraction typically done at room temperature
requires heating.fix: Separating funnel technique uses room temperature shaking and settling
requires heating.action: No heat needed; just shake, vent, settle, and drain

persistent.action: Add mixture, shake, let layers separate, drain lower layer through stopcock

crystallisation.name: Recrystallisation
crystallisation.correct: Recrystallisation purifies solids by dissolving in hot solvent and crystallising on cooling

uses cold solvent first.fix: Dissolve in minimum hot solvent, then cool to crystallise pure compound
uses cold solvent first.action: Hot to dissolve all, cool to crystallise pure product

impurities crystallise out.fix: Impurities stay dissolved; pure product crystallises
impurities crystallise out.action: Impurities remain in mother liquor; crystals are filtered

any solvent works equally well.fix: Ideal solvent: compound soluble hot, insoluble cold; impurities always soluble
any solvent works equally well.action: Choose solvent where product solubility changes greatly with temperature

persistent.action: Dissolve hot (small volume), filter hot, cool slowly for pure crystals

chromatography.name: Chromatography
chromatography.correct: Chromatography separates compounds based on differential movement through stationary and mobile phases

only works for coloured compounds.error: Name suggests colour but not limited to it
only works for coloured compounds.fix: Works for any compound; colourless compounds detected by UV or staining

compounds stay still.fix: Compounds move at different rates depending on affinity for each phase
compounds stay still.action: More affinity for mobile phase = faster movement

one technique only.fix: TLC, column chromatography, HPLC, GC are all chromatography variants
one technique only.action: Same principle, different formats and scales

persistent.action: Compounds partition between phases; different partition = different speed

natural-products.name: Natural Products
natural-products.correct: Many medicines originate from plants, animals, or microorganisms and require extraction and purification

all medicines are synthetic.fix: Many important drugs come from nature: aspirin, penicillin, morphine, taxol
all medicines are synthetic.action: Natural products remain important drug sources and templates

natural products are pure as found.fix: Natural sources contain mixtures; active compounds must be extracted and purified
natural products are pure as found.action: Extraction separates from matrix; purification removes other compounds

extraction changes the compound.fix: Extraction is physical separation, not chemical transformation
extraction changes the compound.action: Compound structure unchanged; just moved from plant to solution

persistent.gap: Not appreciating natural products as medicine sources
persistent.action: Plants contain active compounds that must be extracted and purified

yield-purity.name: Yield vs Purity
yield-purity.correct: Purification often involves trade-off between yield (amount recovered) and purity

high yield always means high purity.fix: More stringent purification improves purity but may reduce yield
high yield always means high purity.action: Balance needed: very pure may mean losing some product

impure product is acceptable.fix: Medicinal products require high purity for safety and efficacy
impure product is acceptable.action: Impurities can be toxic or reduce effectiveness

yield doesn't matter.error: Economic and practical importance of yield
yield doesn't matter.fix: Low yield makes medicines expensive and unsustainable
yield doesn't matter.action: Optimise procedures to balance yield and purity

persistent.gap: Not considering yield-purity trade-off in purification
persistent.action: Aim for high purity at acceptable yield; repeat extraction if needed

purity-testing.name: Purity Assessment
purity-testing.correct: Melting point, chromatography, and spectroscopy can assess product purity

visual inspection is sufficient.fix: Analytical techniques required to detect low-level impurities
visual inspection is sufficient.action: Use melting point, TLC, HPLC, or spectroscopy for purity testing

single technique proves purity.fix: Different techniques detect different types of impurities
single technique proves purity.action: Combine methods: melting point + chromatography + spectroscopy

impurities raise melting point.fix: Impurities lower and broaden the melting point range
impurities raise melting point.action: Sharp melting point near literature value indicates purity

persistent.gap: Not using appropriate purity assessment methods
persistent.action: Sharp melting point + single TLC spot + clean spectrum = pure

explanations.solvent-extraction: Solvent extraction separates compounds based on different solubilities in immiscible solvents (like dissolves like).
explanations.partition-coefficient: Partition coefficient K = [organic]/[aqueous]; higher K means compound prefers organic layer.
explanations.separating-funnel: Separating funnel allows physical separation of immiscible layers; drain denser layer first.
explanations.crystallisation: Recrystallisation: dissolve in minimum hot solvent, filter hot, cool slowly for pure crystals.
explanations.chromatography: Chromatography separates by differential movement; more mobile phase affinity = faster movement.
explanations.natural-products: Many medicines come from nature; active compounds require extraction and purification.
explanations.yield-purity: Purification involves yield-purity trade-off; medicines require high purity even at yield cost.
explanations.purity-testing: Assess purity by sharp melting point, single TLC spot, clean NMR spectrum, and HPLC analysis.
